The "Civil Rights History Project Act of 2009" recognizes the importance of individuals standing up for their rights and beliefs, citing the actions of those involved in the Civil Rights movement as examples. The Act highlights events like the Montgomery Bus Boycott, sit-ins, Freedom Rides, March on Washington, and the drive for voting rights in Mississippi. It acknowledges both well-known leaders like Thurgood Marshall and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., as well as lesser-known individuals who played significant roles in the movement. The Civil Rights movement had many leaders like Thurgood Marshall, Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., and Rosa Parks, but there were also lesser-known individuals whose impact was equally important. Collecting oral histories from Civil Rights participants will provide a detailed history for future generations to learn about their struggle and sacrifice. A project to collect oral histories from individuals involved in the Civil Rights movement will provide a rich history for future generations. The Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution are suitable repositories for preserving and making these oral histories available to the public. The purpose of this Act is to create a federally sponsored project to collect video and audio recordings of personal histories from individuals who participated in the American Civil Rights movement. The Library of Congress and the Smithsonian Institution will preserve and make these oral histories available to the public. The Act establishes a federally sponsored project to collect video and audio recordings of personal histories from participants in the American Civil Rights movement. The project will be coordinated nationally and aims to preserve the memories of individuals involved in the movement for future generations to appreciate. The National Museum of African American History and Culture is collecting video and audio recordings of participants in the American Civil Rights movement. The project, established by the Librarian of Congress and the Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution, aims to survey existing collections and gather reminiscences to preserve the history of the movement. The project aims to collect video and audio recordings, as well as visual and written materials, from individuals who participated in the Civil Rights movement. The goal is to create a collection of these materials, catalog, and index them appropriately. The project aims to collect personal histories, recordings, and materials related to the Civil Rights movement. The collection will be cataloged and made available to the public through the Library of Congress and the National Museum of African American History and Culture. The Secretary will oversee these duties through the Director of the National Museum. The Secretary will carry out duties through the Director of the National Museum. Agreements with other entities may be used for activities, and guidelines will be developed for acquiring recordings. Services of experts and consultants may be procured for project activities. The Librarian and the Secretary may procure services, accept volunteer services, and make advance payments for collecting recordings under the project. The Librarian and the Secretary will collect video and audio recordings related to the Civil Rights movement, starting with the oldest individuals involved. Private support for the project is encouraged through donations. African Americans challenged racial segregation from 1954 to 1968, achieving equal rights legislation. Private donations are encouraged to support the Civil Rights history project at the Library of Congress. The Librarian of Congress must deposit all donated funds into a dedicated account for supporting specific activities. These funds can only be used for the designated activities, and any other donations must not be deposited into this account.
